TO SHIP GRAIN FROM QUEBEC.
THE GREAT NORTHERN RAILWAY WILL con-


Meet THAT CITY WITH LAKE GRAIN BOATS.


Montreal Sept 20 (SpeciaD.-The Great Northern
Railway is all but completed. and will within
a month take It's place as of the great grain
carrying roads Of Canada This road. starting
from Quebec, runs in a southwesterly direction to
Hawkesbury, Ontario, where It joins the Canada
Atlantic system. which to Parry Sound on
the Georgian Bay and has in connection with 1t
a fleet Of grain boats on the upper Great Lakes.
The great bridge over the Ottawa River is not
yet altogether completed. but trains will be able
to cross by the middle of October. and the line
will then be formally opened to traffic. In order
railway has built a million bushel elevator at
Quebec.


The company thinks that Quebec and not Mon
treal is the natural outlet for the ST. Lawrence
route and with a view of doing business with
barges that may have passed Montreal has added
a marine tower that can transship wheat either
into the elevator or an ocean steamer at the rate
of 1900 bushels an hour. The company has made
an arrangement with leading English steamship
service to Great Britain. Large vessels are 70
be used. Steamships to carry this seasons grain
have also been contracted for. The Great North
ern will also build spur from toilette into Mon
treal. a distance of rhirty-stX miles The chieI
difficulty in the way of doing this is the necessity
of bridging the river but II is promised that the
road will be running into Montreal In a year
time.
RAILROAD INTERESTS.

TO SHIP GRAIN FROM QUEBEC.
THE GREAT NORTHERN RAILWAY WILL, CO.

Washington, Sept. % (SpeciaD.-The Treasury
Department to-day exonerated Gilbert Taylor, a
messenger and watchman at the NewYork Barge
Office who charged among other with scan
dalous conduct. Commissioner Fitchie having
found no grounds for his dismissal The In
vestgating Committee which examined the affairs
of the Barge Office specifically stated in its report
that 1t believed ''the success of any recommended
tions 1t could make that could be made. having
for their purpose a correct administration of the
Barge Office would be dependent upon the dis
missal of the present Assistant Commissioner. Ed
ward F. McSweeney and the other officials dn-
cludng Taylor. who had accepted bribes been
guilty Of brutality to women etc.


McSweeney has not been officially informed OF
the committees findings concerning his alleged
disgraceful actions. Molthan. who not men
toned in the report being among those who
should be dismissed, dropped last Saturday
The officials do consider the recommendation
of the Investigation Committee final but are
disposed to remove some employees and exonerate
others regardless OF the report. Assistant Secre-
tary Taylor said to-day that in about week de-
cisions will be made concerning all the employees

was looked upon as common disturber by
Captain Herlihy when he requested action from
the police that would have been construed as

Mr.. Paddock appeared on the scene as dis

The announcement in The Tribune that a plan
of merger of the Big Four (the Cleveland, Cincin-
natl, Chicago and St Lous) Railway Company
with the New-York Central had been drafted. and
was under consideration by William K. Wander
bilt and J. Pierpont Morgan, was accepted by
Wall Street yesterday accurate, although no
formal confirmation from any official source devel-
oped. While the New-York Central has controlled
the Big Four for nearly year, the belief has
been general that it would before long follow the
course which it had adopted with the Lake Shore
the Michigan Central and the West Shore, and IN
crease its holdings of Big Four stock to an amount
which would cradle 1t readily to merge the Big
Four with the New-York Central system.


In the last fortnight there has been unusual
activity in the stock, about 10000 shares OF the
common having changed hands, and in the last
week the common stock has made q net advance Of
three points, the close yesterday having been at
81 and the preferred has advanced 32 points, clos
ing at 1101a-fgures which indicate to the mind Of
Wall Street that something is up; that somebody
is acquiring the stock for a purpose. The Big
Four. which has termini at Sandusky and Cleve-
BELTETED IN WALL STREET.

PLAN OF MERGER OF THE BIG FOUR AND
THE NETWORK CENTRAL EX-


CITES INTEREST.

Fort Worth, Tex. Sept. 29.-Trinity River con-
tnued to rise yesterday and last night. The depth
here IS thirty-hve feet The waters now reach out
over mile In the valley. inundating the entire
bottoms. Many valuable farms have been ruined
and crops destroyed. The Rock Island bridge over
Westfork. Newark has been washed away.


Much of the Cotton Belt railroad track has been
carried away. The Cotton Belt station is sur
rounded with water three four feet deep. and all
business is suspended temporarily. trains canot
get into the yards within mile OF them.


The waters have interfered with the running OF
trains and streetcars in the city Service over the
North Side streetcar lines has been abandoned. II
has been many years since the waters OF the Trim
ity have reached such high stage


As vet loss OF life has been reported. but IL Is
believed that possibly some people have perished
below this city In the Trinity River bottoms from
the unprecedented overflow The people below here
were not informed of the great rise they were
at this point The damage TO farms along the
river Will be very great. and possibly the loss will
reach 100000


Last night water surrounding the waterworks sta
tion three feet deep. II the flood continues to
rise damage 20 the waterworks cannot be averted.
The family OF Captain Samuel Evans were saved
from the swollen stream by friends who went TO
them with rOwboat- There have been several
other narrow escapes.
HIGH WATER IN TRINITY RIVER.

MUCH DAMAGE DONE BY THE FLoOD-Loss OF


LIFE FEARED.

Norfolk Va Sept. 29-The United States Light
house Board has given notice that 1t will establish
light vessel No. Il at the tail of the horseshoe.
The vessel will be placed in position or about
October II It Will be established in about five
and a half fathOms of water approximately In the
position now occupied by Junction bell buoy. to
seaward of the southeasterly end of the tail of the
horseshoe in the entrance to Chesapeake Bay
and at the junction of the main ship channel up
the bay with the channel to Hampton Roads. The
vessel will show two fixed white lights, one from
each masthead and each produced by three lens
lanters encircling the masthead. The focal plane
of each light will be ffty-six feet above the sea-
and the lights will be visible thirteen miles in clear
weather the observers eye fifteen feet above the
NEW LIGHT AT CHESAPEAKE ENTRANCE

men whom you liked? That is wherein the
saloon-the jokes are cracked and the stories
are told and the news is exchanged


And after the saloon habit got fastened
you. wouldn't you be likely to choose female
I society plane with 1t? And after you drank
too hard and life became desperate and souless,
and the prospect of State prison or hell itself
ceased to startle or worry you and some early
morning YOU saw a richly dressed man reeling
along your block, wouldn't you take a chance
the penitentiary term and get his money.
whether you had to knock him in the head or
not? Just likely not you would. 1t would
be entirely natural and logical. That is why the
citizen in luxurious circumstances should be-
come interested in the work here-not necessa-
ry the work of this particular parish, but mis-
sion work in this city.


There is really little opportunity for a small
boy to let off his surplus steam to use hgure
He cannot do much of anything to have any
fun. He ought to be forgiven when he engages
in a street fight with another urchin or tips
over a pushcart. The country boy would take
It out in climbing trees playing with his dog or
running and jumping with his schoolmates II
the boys and girls TO be made into good men
and women they must have something new to
do The dreary and harmful things which oc-
cupy their minds now must be expelled with
something which they will love better


GYMNASIUM A BENEFICENT AGENCY.


Our gymnasium here is a great help. 1t is
open every night for boys and girls and men.
and in the afternoon it is open for the boys who
do not work during the day. The boys have
horizontal bars, dumbbells. CLUBS boxing gloves
and shower baths. These things give them
change, and when they are exercising 1t gives
the clergymen and assistants an opportunity to
get at them and to talk TO them on temperance
and purity, and those things which tend direct
" TO make the body stronger and the eye ana
muscle quicker The gymnasium is among the
most powerful forces for the betterment OF
social conditions. It gives the boys and girls
a chance, if you will pardon the expression, to
get tired legitimately. that afterward sleep
will be wholesome and the mind will be COM
posed We do not allow boxing to go to brutal
extent Boxing is helpful, because it teaches the
boys TO control their tempers and to remember
that others are just as skilful as themselves. 1t
would pay the city in the long run 10 estaolls9
running tracks and baseball grounds all around
the East Side. If. when feeling nervous and
discouraged our East Side boys could run
around the tanbark or jump into plunge bath
instead of going to a saloon and filling up with
whiskey, the future citizen would be a gooo
deal better off We have a cadet corps of about
eeyantv-6Z,e members. drilled by 7th Regiment
captain who loves the work While they are
taught to handle guns. stand straight and
obey orders they also taught to love the
nag TO take pride in civic honesty and TO re-
spect women.


AS a result Of certain Investigations made in
the last six months. mission workers on the
Fast Side have been compelled TO take notice
OF the fact that the conditions which became
,,rbearable in 1893 and 1894. preceding the
I,exow investigation, are fully as bad now. and
that the prevalence Of vice, with the knowledge,
~ not with the promotion. of officers of the law
is spreading from its old strongholds into new
localities


There was a llIIle "HCl <AilclI-S'' 'A4OA40 "'~N
nv common consent called the bailiwick of disor-
derly women. Other streets were known to
barbor them, but, generally speaking they re-
uained in Allen-st. Now there are other streets
lust as bad as Alen-st. Some OF them are
Chrystie Forsyth Delaney, First Second
Third Fourth. Eighth and Ninth SITS. Second
ave between Fourteenth-st, and StuyVesant
Square, and East Houston-st.


AS matter of fact. the Twelfth and Fiji
teenth precincts are besprinkled with these un-
fcrtunates. and the old system Of assessing them
for police protection is known to be in full
swing


THE OLD PROTECTION" SYSTEM


A man interested in the University Settlement
work said TO a Tribune reporter yesterday:


The old system of protection to vice in all its
responsiveness and wickedness is in complete
oneration again. and that is why Mr.. Paddock

THE MOLINEUX CASE


Judge John Clinton Gray. of the New-York State
Court of Appeals. arrived here yesterday from
Southampton the American Line steamer St
Louis He went abroad early in June partly on ac-
count of Ill health. He spent the entire time in
England. The Paris Exposition. he said yesterday
did not attract him, because he heard so many
expressions of disappointment regarding 1t from
those who did attend It,


AS he left the steamer a reporter asked him
about the progress of the Molineux case


This case" he said, will be a very wearyine
one to try. because the Judge is Obliged to base
ms decision upon his construction of the facts as
well as OF the questions of law. This means to a
conscientious judge that the entire testimony must
be gone over. Until few years ago. when law
was passed requiring 1t, the Court of Appeals was
,6 no1 expected to pass upon the question of fact
Judge Gray 1880
JUDGE GRAY RETURNS HOME.

ously when he takes up the task OF clearing the
mission field occupied by the parish OF the Pro-
Cathedral Of illegitimate and uncalled for OBJ
structions there is little doubt in the minds of
those who possess the Bishops confidence.


In 1895 Bishop Potter spent a month Of his
annual vacation at the Pro-Cathedral, work
ing among the people Of the tenements At the
end OF that time his labor had become so fasci-
mating to him that he went back to his ac-
custorned tasks with considerable reluctance.
Since then he has more than once expressed a
desire 70 engage again in practical day by day
mission work al the Stanton-st- church.


The resolution adopted by the Diocesan Con-
vention directing Bishop Potter TO investigate
the alleged indignities offered by the police TO
the Rev. Robert L. Paddock, who merely asked
the police to DO their duty. has aroused wide
spread interest in the city and is causing a
great deal Of uneasiness at Police Headquarters.
The suggestion was made yesterday that Rich
ard Croker was anxious to get rid Of Chief
Devery. and that if Bishop Potter made serious
charges against Inspector Cross Devery would
be promptly retired for not keeping things in
better shape in the Department Cross's friends
say that ne will remain in the Department with
out doubt as he is in line for promotion to the
Office Of Chief


President York Of the Police Board said yes
terdsy that he understood that the entire trouble
came from the alleged insult offered the Rev.
Mr Paddock by Captain Herlihy. He asserted
that he was going to investigate the circum-
stances and If It was found that Herlihy in
suited Ny. Paddock he would compel Herhy
10 apologize or take action against him. In
spector Cross's friends said yesterday that he
was going TO try 10 see Bishop Potter personally
and smooth over the matter, that he, Cross
would not appear in his present bad light


CROSS SEES YORK.


Inspector Cross was closeted with President
York yesterday afternoon for two hours, talking
about the charges made against him and cap
tain Herlihy. After the consultation President
York was asked II any action would be taken
bv the Board and he said he did not know.


The whole matter now rests with Bishop
Potter" he said and until we hear from him
nothing viii be done. am certain he VIII be
fair in the matter and any report he makes or
any complaint will doubtless be a just one


Mr. Paddock meanwhile is quietly doing his
accustomed work among the tenement mousse
people in and Stanton-st- He Is son OF
the late Bishop John A Paddock. Of Washing
ton State, and has been attached to the FRO
Cathedral for the last two years. IN that time
he has become acquainted with the social con-
ditions Of the neighborhood and when he says
that the tendency seems to be downward IN
stead Of upward, and that the police instead OF
assisting IN the amelioration OF the conullionS
there deliberately and Systematically oostruct
and retard the work he speaks with positive
knowledge.


Speaking Of the conditions on the East Slde
yesterday. Mr.. Paddock said:


The work here certainly merits the earnest
consideration Of thoughtful men interested IN
the welfare Of the city. There is a growing uIi-
rest The conditions well calculated 10
breed anarchy and eventual violence. one uoes
not need 70 be an alarmist to see the pIiLom9 pI
ahead. We need encouragement from SUI stIVHs -
men The rich men Of the city who mo II
dfficult TO interest their in business en-
terprises should encourage some or theh 70
come over here and take part in our extremely
interesting work There ought TO be a coiiese
or university settlement on every BLOCK


A PICTURE OF EAST SIDE CONDITIONS.

Suppose that you were the child Of drunkaro.
here in this tenement district, or that your

Harrisburg Penn, Sept. 29.-George H. Welshons,
Of the best known newspaper men In Pennsyl-
vania committed suicide by severing the arteries
on his with penknife this evening in bed
room of a Harrisburg hotel. Weshons had
been drinking hard since he came to this city
two weeks ago. and labored under the hallucnaton
that he pursued by enemies He left this mes
sage. which written in a clear hand, on the
wall of the room: Facing my God, die innocent
and believing in my wife's fidelity. The future will
aCquit me- Welshons was formerly member of
the State Committee, and in the last GovernOrship
convention he had charge of the press bureau at
the Republican State headquarters.
SUICIDE OF NEWsPAPER MAN

Bishop Potter is in position 10 make puh,,o
conclusive proof of downright oppression nv,
the police Of the Eldridgest station Of scores Of
people who have come within the influence of
the parish work Of the Pro-Cathedral in stan
ton-st. He viii be able. If he so das,ras 80
show that petty prosecutions by the officers %
the law have made the work of Christian mon
and women who are trying to better the CON


ditions of the poor extremely hard in the lower
East Side. That he will work and talk v,sor-

WELL EQUIPPED FOR THE FIGHT
AGAINST POLICE OPPRESSION ON .


THE EAST SIDE.

Five men arrested yesterday by Acting Cap
tain Maude. OF the Hamiton-ave. police station.
after he had been cruising in the Atlantic Basin
in search OF them for some time. The Pennsyl-
vania Railroad had been missing pig iron from
barge on the South Brooklyn waterfront The po-
lice learned that several men leaving pig iron
at McCormacks junk shop. No. 10 Harrison-st.
The men were finally found, and escaped on a
FIVE CAPTURED AFTER A CRUISE.

Newport News. Va, Sept. % (SpeciaD.-The
Chesapeake and Ohio Railway recently secured the
entire stock Of the Coastwise Steamship Company
and now controls it outright. The Coastwise COM
pany is engaged in shipping coal from Newport
News to New-Engand ports. 1t owns three ocean
tugs fifteen large coal barges and charters three
ocean steamers. 1t is doing probably a larger
coal business than any other coastwise shipping
company.


1t is announced to-day that beginning on Mon
day, the price Of Pocahontas steam coal will be
advanced 10 cents ton, due to the heavy demand
for steam coal caused by the Pennsylvania strike
AS far as known the Chesapeake and Ohio Rail
way, operating here. win not increase the price
of it's New River steam coal for which there is a
heavier demand now than ever before.
NEW CONTROL OF CoAsTWIsE COMPANY.

CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO WILL SHIP COAL TO


EW-ENGLAND PORTS.

Washington. Sept 90 CSpeciaD-Through the
efforts Of Congressman James F. Stewart of the
With New-Jersey Congress District. the Postoffice
Department has allowed a reimbursement OF POST
master McMuen. of Rochelle Park N J.. for $40
in stamps stolen from the postolce at that place.
Mr. Stewart has also secured pensions for John
Terhune Of Hackensack. n. j., and James Hand.
Of Paterson, n. j. Application for postoffice at
Hudson Heights, Bergen County, n. j., was made
by the same Congressman
pOSTuASTER REIvBrRSED

A conference of the New-Jersey Democratic State
Committee was held yesterday afternoon at the
headquarters in Jersey City 1t decided to
have Mr.. Bryan speak in Jersey City October 25
The meeting will be held under the auspices of the
Hudson County Democratic Committee. with
view OF patching up the differences between the
local committee and Chairman Courley. The State
Committee completed arrangements for the con-
vention of the New-Jersey Democratic Clubs In
Trenton on October Is.
BRYAN IN NEW-JERSEY.

Washington, Sept. 29.-Owing to the advance in
the price OF silver the Director OF the Mint. Mr..
Roberts, to-day increased the price to be paid by
the Government for silver purchased from So cents
10 81 cents a standard ounce. The Government at
present purchases only such silver is contained
in gold deposits from the Klondike and other gold
producing sections Under the existing statute all
silver In gold deposits is paid for at the market
price The price has advanced steadily since 1895.
when It touched n cents for a standard ounce. The
new price is to go into effect on Monday.


The Director of the Mint also has changed the
Indian rupee from its silver to it's gold value to go
Although England placed India gold basis
some time ago, official informatan was received
to that effect until recently The silver rupee had
previously been the standard Indian coin. and was
valued 20.5 cents. Under the gold standard the
sovereign succeeds the rupee the standard, and
hereafter the rupee will be reckoned at its gold
value. 32.4 cents
PRICE OF SILVER INCREASED.

FIXED AT 81 CENTS AN OUNCE BY THE DIRECTOR


OF THE MINT.

New-Haven. Conn. Sept 29.-The Old Guard, Of
New-York. commanded by Major S. Ellis Briggs.
came New-Haven to-day as guests of the I'd
Company. Governors Foot Guards. The business
blocks and many private houses were decorated
in honor Of the visitors After a tour about the
city they entertained at luncheon at the
home OF Major Edward Clark of the Foot Guards
their visitors attended by an escort of police
paraded the principal streets of the city and at
o'clock dinner served at the Hotel Tontine.
rHE on GUARD AT NEN.HArEN.

The next International Railway Congress will be
held in Washington in October, 1904. cable dis
patch from w. F. Allen. secretary of the American
Railway Association announcing that fact was re-
ceived yesterday the offices OF the association.
Mr.. Allen who is of the American delegates to
the International Railway Congress which has been
in session in the French capital during the last
week says that pressing invitation by the dele
gates from this country had been extended to the
Congress- and that the members of that body had
informed Mr. Allen of their acceptance.


The following officials of American railways have
been In attendance at the sixth session OF the In
ternational Congress- which closed yesterday: L.
F. Loree general manager Pennsylvania lines west
of Pittsburg; ]. Ramsey, jr., v!ce-presdent and
general manager Wabash; j. T. Harahan. second
vice-president Illinois Central; c. w Buchholz
chief engineer Erie; s T. Crapo general manager
Flint and Pere Marquette; G. L. BretZ. general
manager West Virginia Central and Pittsburg; Paul
Didier assistant chief engineer Pittsburg and
WESTERN c. P. Clark director New-York New
Haven and Hartford: P. H. Dudley. inspecting an
gineer New-York Central: DR. c. B. Dudley. chem
ist Pennsylvania: A NJ. Gibbs. assistant mechanical
engineer Pennsylvania; Colonel James L. Taylor.
Pennsylvania: Martin a. Knapp chairman OF the
Interstate Commerce Commission, and W. F. Allen,
secretary of the American Railway Association.
WORLDS RAILWAY CONGRESS IN 1901

MEETING JUST CLOSING IN PARIS.

Montclair, n. j., Sept % (SpeciaD.-Henry Dob
bins said to be a New-York business man, was
held in $500 bail by Recorder Yost to-day on a
charge of breaking and entering. made by Miss
Dora Taft. Dobbins boarded with the complainant
during the summer. He refused 1t Is said TO pay
a bill Of $32 for the use of a barn as a storage place
for his automobile He paid his board bill yester-
day. before returning TO New York out declined
pay the bill for storage and. is alleged sawed
the lock off the barn and got his automobile when
bir
cHARGED WITH BREAKING AND ENTERING.

Long Branch. ". J., Sept. % (SpecaD.-The Daniel
DouShe-ty cottage. in Ocean-ave.. at the West End
occupied by Fritz Loeb. OF No. 541 Madison-aye.
New-York and the Lane cottage, In Chelsea-sve.
where Uriah Herman and family are living, were
entered by thieves at early hour this morning
Mr. Loeb's loss is said TO be 1900. which includes
s1s5 in cash. a watch and chain and breastpin.
the latter being a highly priced gem. Mr.. Her
mans loss was small. The thieves were discovered
in time to prevent wholesale robbery, but they
escaped and stin at large.
COTTAGES ROBBED AT LONG BRAycH.

San Antonio, Tex, Sept. 29.-United States Consul
w. w Mills, at Chihuahua. Mex, has sent note
to the Federal authorities here and also the
State Department at Washington detailing an in
suit to the American flag his consulate
September 16. the anniversary of Mexican inde-
pendence. by mob of Mexcans. He had hoisted
the United States and Mexican flags in honor of
the day. and the mob tore down the United States
AMERICAN FLAG PULLED DOWN IN MEXICO

washington Sept. alt has been decided 20 sell
the old single turret monitor Nantucket and the tug
Cheyenne A Naval Board recently appraised the
former at $50 and the latter 5000. No bids
were received on September q. when proposals
to be opened for the purchase OF the ships.
and bids will be invited again.
TWO NAVAL VESSELS FOR SALE.

San Francisco Sept. 2s-"The Examiner to-day
says that the latest gossip in Southern Pacific
circles is that James Speyer. Charles H. Tweed and
D. o. Mills as a special committee of the director
ate have offered H e Huntington the presidency
of the company, but that he has declined 1t on the
ground that his duties first vce-president OF the
road together with the work of looking after the
large fortune left him by his uncle. will more than
occupy his time


The officials who indulging in talk of this
character assert that H. Z. Huntington does not
want outsider president. His particular can
didate for the place is the third cepresident j..
G. Stubbs. He also wants. 1t is said. Edwin Haw-
ley. of New-York. to succeed c. P. Huntington as
president of the Pacific Mail
PRESIDENCY OF SOUTHERN PACIFIC.

washington. Sept 2s.-Lleutenant Hobson has sp-
piled to the Navy Department for six months
leave OF absence because OF trouble with his eyes
He has experienced considerable pain In his eyes
OF late. particularly when exposed 70 a strong
light. and Il Is understood that specialist has
recommended a complete rest for six months.
HOBsoy ASKS SIN MONTHS LEAVE.

North Tonawanda, N Y, Sept. pa sensation
was sprung the Genesee Methodist Conference
when 1t learned that Bishop McCabe had
called a clergyman before him and threatened him
with discipline unless he desisted from preaching
heretical doctrines The preacher taught the doc
trines of organization called the Christian and
Missionary Alliance, Of which DR.. Simpson, of
Newly orf. is the leader This believes in
the laying on Of hands for the cure of physical i'll
The clergyman used his influence for the
advancement of the faith healing ideas until there
has been much division and some Withdrawals
from his church
METH0D1sTs OPPOSE FAITH CURE.

LATIoN OF STATES THIS WEEK.


washington, Sept. 29-The Census Bureau to-
day finished the enumeration of all the cities in
the United States of 25.OOO inha abitants with
the exception OF Los Angeles Cal, and
Seattle and Tacoma Wash. The work Of an
nouncing the population OF States will come next
beginning with Arkansas probably next Monde
or Tuesday. The States will be announced in short
bulletins giving the total population. increase over
the two preceding census reports. the popula alton
by counties and the population OF each Of the
under 25,Ooo' Including all the incorporated towns
within the State limits. II is hoped to complete
the work on the States by the time Congress
assemblies, after which the vital statistics will be
pushed.


It IS probable that the present census will cost
in the neighborhood Of S15OOO,O00.
PROGRESS OF CENSUS WORK.

THE BUREAU WILL BEGIN TO ANNOUNCE PoPu-


LATIoN OF STATES THIS WEEK.

n,er after an exciting chase. They were captured
again. however. by policemen who had been sta
toned at the entrance to the pier In court the
prisoners were held in $3.50 bail suspicious per-

OF PEDESTRIAN.


Mrs. Margaret Gilman. eighty-three years old.
OF No. 273 Madson-ave.. with her maid, Miss c.
Mcguire, was passing No II East hirty-eighth-st.
yesterday afternoon. when lighted lamp struck
the sidewalk directly In front of her. The lamp
was broken and the oil famed up setting fire TO
the clothing OF Mrs. Gilman. Miss Mcguire
promptly beat out the flames with her hands. Sc
verely burning them and her arms in doing so.
Mrs. Gilman not injured. The two women
entered a cab and were driven home


The lamp was thrown from the second floor of
the building by Fritz Gunther. decorator. who
lives at No. SlS Cedar Place. in The Bronx. He
was at work in the building. when the wick of the
lamp suddenly hared UP. Fearing that the infam-
mable material with which he was working would
become ignited, Gunther grabbed the lamp and
threw II into the street. Mrs Gilman refused 70
make n complaint against Gunther, and he not
arrested.
THROWS LAMP AT WoMEN's FEET.

woRKINGMANs ACT IMPERILs THE LIFE


OF PEDESTRIAN

Mrs. Mary Catherwood, wife of Samuel Gather
wood. of No. 35l Fifteenth-ave.. Newark. n. J..
gave birth yesterday to a child without arms or
otherwise.
BORN WTTHOrT ARns OR LEGS.

Plainfeld, n. Y, Sept 2e.-Suit has been begun
by J. D. Spcer. of the firm of Spcer & Hubbard
mill owners. in this city, for 1000 against the
lumber firm of Boice, Runyon & Co., for injuries
received last spring by the breaking of a scaffold
IN the lumber yard. The suit is in reality against
the Travellers Insurance Company. but has to be
brought against the firm, which insured
against accidents of this kind.


Mr.. Spicer and John D. Runyon the scat
fold twenty feet from the ground, examining um-
Der. when the scaffold broke. Mr. Runyon died
from his injuries but Mr.. Spicer after long ILL
ness Is able to be about again.
SUIT AGAINST A LUMBER FIRM.

PLA1NFIELD MILL OWNER INJURED BY A BREAK


ING sCAFFoLD WANTS $4,000

ALMOST EVERY BRANCH OF INDUSTRY
is represented in the little advertisements Of the
people In the narrow columns.

THE REAL THING
in bargains may be found IN the little advsrtfse-
ments OF the people In the narrow columns ~ to-
days papo--

full articles.headline:
RAILROAD INTERESTS.

TO SHIP GRAIN FROM QUEBEC.
THE GREAT NORTHERN RAILWAY WILL, CO.
full articles.article:
TO SHIP GRAIN FROM QUEBEC.
THE GREAT NORTHERN RAILWAY WILL con-


Meet THAT CITY WITH LAKE GRAIN BOATS.


Montreal Sept 20 (SpeciaD.-The Great Northern
Railway is all but completed. and will within
a month take It's place as of the great grain
carrying roads Of Canada This road. starting
from Quebec, runs in a southwesterly direction to
Hawkesbury, Ontario, where It joins the Canada
Atlantic system. which to Parry Sound on
the Georgian Bay and has in connection with 1t
a fleet Of grain boats on the upper Great Lakes.
The great bridge over the Ottawa River is not
yet altogether completed. but trains will be able
to cross by the middle of October. and the line
will then be formally opened to traffic. In order
railway has built a million bushel elevator at
Quebec.


The company thinks that Quebec and not Mon
treal is the natural outlet for the ST. Lawrence
route and with a view of doing business with
barges that may have passed Montreal has added
a marine tower that can transship wheat either
into the elevator or an ocean steamer at the rate
of 1900 bushels an hour. The company has made
an arrangement with leading English steamship
service to Great Britain. Large vessels are 70
be used. Steamships to carry this seasons grain
have also been contracted for. The Great North
ern will also build spur from toilette into Mon
treal. a distance of rhirty-stX miles The chieI
difficulty in the way of doing this is the necessity
of bridging the river but II is promised that the
road will be running into Montreal In a year
time.

full articles.headline: BARGE OFFICE W4TCHmAN ExONERATED
full articles.article:
Washington, Sept. % (SpeciaD.-The Treasury
Department to-day exonerated Gilbert Taylor, a
messenger and watchman at the NewYork Barge
Office who charged among other with scan
dalous conduct. Commissioner Fitchie having
found no grounds for his dismissal The In
vestgating Committee which examined the affairs
of the Barge Office specifically stated in its report
that 1t believed ''the success of any recommended
tions 1t could make that could be made. having
for their purpose a correct administration of the
Barge Office would be dependent upon the dis
missal of the present Assistant Commissioner. Ed
ward F. McSweeney and the other officials dn-
cludng Taylor. who had accepted bribes been
guilty Of brutality to women etc.


McSweeney has not been officially informed OF
the committees findings concerning his alleged
disgraceful actions. Molthan. who not men
toned in the report being among those who
should be dismissed, dropped last Saturday
The officials do consider the recommendation
of the Investigation Committee final but are
disposed to remove some employees and exonerate
others regardless OF the report. Assistant Secre-
tary Taylor said to-day that in about week de-
cisions will be made concerning all the employees

full articles.headline: YORK DAILY TRIBUNE. SUNDAY. SEPTEMBER 1900.
full articles.article:
~ ~aaener ana mother both We're dead. You would
Slo" up hungry and dirty. The few clothes you
tice " ~oulu @ oe shabby. The most frequent prac
uce OF your guardians and superiors would per
maps oe tnat of deceit And when you got a lit
He oluer instead of having green fields to play
III ana innocent and happy companions or in
oetesuhg animal pets, as do many country boys;
NhaI II you had the same old monotonous sur
IouIhulhss' the same old smells, the same old
n,UiSes-Woulont you get desperately tired of II
al ana suppose little later you earned few
cents day, and, not having any better place
10 CO. you visited some of these East Side candy
stores, where soda water and cigarettes are so
cheap. If you were invited into the back room
OF some or them and asked to shoot craps"
WIN other boys wouldn't you, with nothing bet
Ter to DO. and nothing to prevent you, probably
take hand in It?


and then a little later, when the candy shop
grew 10 be an old story and you earned more
money ana had your evenings to yourself
wouldn't you go TO the saloon with other young

was looked upon as common disturber by
Captain Herlihy when he requested action from
the police that would have been construed as
hostility to the disorderly elements. These
women had paid their dues to the police, and by
a crude and mighty dangerous sense OF honor
certain police officials consider that they ought
to have something in return for their money.
Mr.. Paddock appeared on the scene as dis
turber. Hence his treatment. Herlihy is not so
much to blame for his hostility to Mr.. Paddock
and his friends as most people too hastily as
sumo He's got his orders. and, as they say In
police circles. he knows his book" The trou-
BILE is higher up in the Police Department.
have no sympathy for those who say that poll
tics ought to be kept out of this agitation for
the rights of the poor against their oppressors.
political machine is directly back Of the police
officials who directing the control of the rank
and file. Until the political machine is routed,
there will be no change.

full articles.headline:
BELTETED IN WALL STREET.

PLAN OF MERGER OF THE BIG FOUR AND
THE NETWORK CENTRAL EX-


CITES INTEREST.
full articles.article:
The announcement in The Tribune that a plan
of merger of the Big Four (the Cleveland, Cincin-
natl, Chicago and St Lous) Railway Company
with the New-York Central had been drafted. and
was under consideration by William K. Wander
bilt and J. Pierpont Morgan, was accepted by
Wall Street yesterday accurate, although no
formal confirmation from any official source devel-
oped. While the New-York Central has controlled
the Big Four for nearly year, the belief has
been general that it would before long follow the
course which it had adopted with the Lake Shore
the Michigan Central and the West Shore, and IN
crease its holdings of Big Four stock to an amount
which would cradle 1t readily to merge the Big
Four with the New-York Central system.


In the last fortnight there has been unusual
activity in the stock, about 10000 shares OF the
common having changed hands, and in the last
week the common stock has made q net advance Of
three points, the close yesterday having been at
81 and the preferred has advanced 32 points, clos
ing at 1101a-fgures which indicate to the mind Of
Wall Street that something is up; that somebody
is acquiring the stock for a purpose. The Big
Four. which has termini at Sandusky and Cleve-

full articles.headline:
HIGH WATER IN TRINITY RIVER.

MUCH DAMAGE DONE BY THE FLoOD-Loss OF


LIFE FEARED.
full articles.article:
Fort Worth, Tex. Sept. 29.-Trinity River con-
tnued to rise yesterday and last night. The depth
here IS thirty-hve feet The waters now reach out
over mile In the valley. inundating the entire
bottoms. Many valuable farms have been ruined
and crops destroyed. The Rock Island bridge over
Westfork. Newark has been washed away.


Much of the Cotton Belt railroad track has been
carried away. The Cotton Belt station is sur
rounded with water three four feet deep. and all
business is suspended temporarily. trains canot
get into the yards within mile OF them.


The waters have interfered with the running OF
trains and streetcars in the city Service over the
North Side streetcar lines has been abandoned. II
has been many years since the waters OF the Trim
ity have reached such high stage


As vet loss OF life has been reported. but IL Is
believed that possibly some people have perished
below this city In the Trinity River bottoms from
the unprecedented overflow The people below here
were not informed of the great rise they were
at this point The damage TO farms along the
river Will be very great. and possibly the loss will
reach 100000


Last night water surrounding the waterworks sta
tion three feet deep. II the flood continues to
rise damage 20 the waterworks cannot be averted.
The family OF Captain Samuel Evans were saved
from the swollen stream by friends who went TO
them with rOwboat- There have been several
other narrow escapes.

full articles.headline: NEW LIGHT AT CHESAPEAKE ENTRANCE
full articles.article:
Norfolk Va Sept. 29-The United States Light
house Board has given notice that 1t will establish
light vessel No. Il at the tail of the horseshoe.
The vessel will be placed in position or about
October II It Will be established in about five
and a half fathOms of water approximately In the
position now occupied by Junction bell buoy. to
seaward of the southeasterly end of the tail of the
horseshoe in the entrance to Chesapeake Bay
and at the junction of the main ship channel up
the bay with the channel to Hampton Roads. The
vessel will show two fixed white lights, one from
each masthead and each produced by three lens
lanters encircling the masthead. The focal plane
of each light will be ffty-six feet above the sea-
and the lights will be visible thirteen miles in clear
weather the observers eye fifteen feet above the

full articles.headline: GYMNASIUM OF THE PRO-cATHEDRAL
full articles.article:
men whom you liked? That is wherein the
saloon-the jokes are cracked and the stories
are told and the news is exchanged


And after the saloon habit got fastened
you. wouldn't you be likely to choose female
I society plane with 1t? And after you drank
too hard and life became desperate and souless,
and the prospect of State prison or hell itself
ceased to startle or worry you and some early
morning YOU saw a richly dressed man reeling
along your block, wouldn't you take a chance
the penitentiary term and get his money.
whether you had to knock him in the head or
not? Just likely not you would. 1t would
be entirely natural and logical. That is why the
citizen in luxurious circumstances should be-
come interested in the work here-not necessa-
ry the work of this particular parish, but mis-
sion work in this city.


There is really little opportunity for a small
boy to let off his surplus steam to use hgure
He cannot do much of anything to have any
fun. He ought to be forgiven when he engages
in a street fight with another urchin or tips
over a pushcart. The country boy would take
It out in climbing trees playing with his dog or
running and jumping with his schoolmates II
the boys and girls TO be made into good men
and women they must have something new to
do The dreary and harmful things which oc-
cupy their minds now must be expelled with
something which they will love better


GYMNASIUM A BENEFICENT AGENCY.


Our gymnasium here is a great help. 1t is
open every night for boys and girls and men.
and in the afternoon it is open for the boys who
do not work during the day. The boys have
horizontal bars, dumbbells. CLUBS boxing gloves
and shower baths. These things give them
change, and when they are exercising 1t gives
the clergymen and assistants an opportunity to
get at them and to talk TO them on temperance
and purity, and those things which tend direct
" TO make the body stronger and the eye ana
muscle quicker The gymnasium is among the
most powerful forces for the betterment OF
social conditions. It gives the boys and girls
a chance, if you will pardon the expression, to
get tired legitimately. that afterward sleep
will be wholesome and the mind will be COM
posed We do not allow boxing to go to brutal
extent Boxing is helpful, because it teaches the
boys TO control their tempers and to remember
that others are just as skilful as themselves. 1t
would pay the city in the long run 10 estaolls9
running tracks and baseball grounds all around
the East Side. If. when feeling nervous and
discouraged our East Side boys could run
around the tanbark or jump into plunge bath
instead of going to a saloon and filling up with
whiskey, the future citizen would be a gooo
deal better off We have a cadet corps of about
eeyantv-6Z,e members. drilled by 7th Regiment
captain who loves the work While they are
taught to handle guns. stand straight and
obey orders they also taught to love the
nag TO take pride in civic honesty and TO re-
spect women.


AS a result Of certain Investigations made in
the last six months. mission workers on the
Fast Side have been compelled TO take notice
OF the fact that the conditions which became
,,rbearable in 1893 and 1894. preceding the
I,exow investigation, are fully as bad now. and
that the prevalence Of vice, with the knowledge,
~ not with the promotion. of officers of the law
is spreading from its old strongholds into new
localities


There was a llIIle "HCl <AilclI-S'' 'A4OA40 "'~N
nv common consent called the bailiwick of disor-
derly women. Other streets were known to
barbor them, but, generally speaking they re-
uained in Allen-st. Now there are other streets
lust as bad as Alen-st. Some OF them are
Chrystie Forsyth Delaney, First Second
Third Fourth. Eighth and Ninth SITS. Second
ave between Fourteenth-st, and StuyVesant
Square, and East Houston-st.


AS matter of fact. the Twelfth and Fiji
teenth precincts are besprinkled with these un-
fcrtunates. and the old system Of assessing them
for police protection is known to be in full
swing


THE OLD PROTECTION" SYSTEM


A man interested in the University Settlement
work said TO a Tribune reporter yesterday:


The old system of protection to vice in all its
responsiveness and wickedness is in complete
oneration again. and that is why Mr.. Paddock

full articles.headline: JUDGE GRAY RETURNS HOME.
full articles.article:
SPENT HIS TIME IN ENGLAND-TALKs OF


THE MOLINEUX CASE


Judge John Clinton Gray. of the New-York State
Court of Appeals. arrived here yesterday from
Southampton the American Line steamer St
Louis He went abroad early in June partly on ac-
count of Ill health. He spent the entire time in
England. The Paris Exposition. he said yesterday
did not attract him, because he heard so many
expressions of disappointment regarding 1t from
those who did attend It,


AS he left the steamer a reporter asked him
about the progress of the Molineux case


This case" he said, will be a very wearyine
one to try. because the Judge is Obliged to base
ms decision upon his construction of the facts as
well as OF the questions of law. This means to a
conscientious judge that the entire testimony must
be gone over. Until few years ago. when law
was passed requiring 1t, the Court of Appeals was
,6 no1 expected to pass upon the question of fact
Judge Gray 1880

ously when he takes up the task OF clearing the
mission field occupied by the parish OF the Pro-
Cathedral Of illegitimate and uncalled for OBJ
structions there is little doubt in the minds of
those who possess the Bishops confidence.


In 1895 Bishop Potter spent a month Of his
annual vacation at the Pro-Cathedral, work
ing among the people Of the tenements At the
end OF that time his labor had become so fasci-
mating to him that he went back to his ac-
custorned tasks with considerable reluctance.
Since then he has more than once expressed a
desire 70 engage again in practical day by day
mission work al the Stanton-st- church.


The resolution adopted by the Diocesan Con-
vention directing Bishop Potter TO investigate
the alleged indignities offered by the police TO
the Rev. Robert L. Paddock, who merely asked
the police to DO their duty. has aroused wide
spread interest in the city and is causing a
great deal Of uneasiness at Police Headquarters.
The suggestion was made yesterday that Rich
ard Croker was anxious to get rid Of Chief
Devery. and that if Bishop Potter made serious
charges against Inspector Cross Devery would
be promptly retired for not keeping things in
better shape in the Department Cross's friends
say that ne will remain in the Department with
out doubt as he is in line for promotion to the
Office Of Chief


President York Of the Police Board said yes
terdsy that he understood that the entire trouble
came from the alleged insult offered the Rev.
Mr Paddock by Captain Herlihy. He asserted
that he was going to investigate the circum-
stances and If It was found that Herlihy in
suited Ny. Paddock he would compel Herhy
10 apologize or take action against him. In
spector Cross's friends said yesterday that he
was going TO try 10 see Bishop Potter personally
and smooth over the matter, that he, Cross
would not appear in his present bad light


CROSS SEES YORK.


Inspector Cross was closeted with President
York yesterday afternoon for two hours, talking
about the charges made against him and cap
tain Herlihy. After the consultation President
York was asked II any action would be taken
bv the Board and he said he did not know.


The whole matter now rests with Bishop
Potter" he said and until we hear from him
nothing viii be done. am certain he VIII be
fair in the matter and any report he makes or
any complaint will doubtless be a just one


Mr. Paddock meanwhile is quietly doing his
accustomed work among the tenement mousse
people in and Stanton-st- He Is son OF
the late Bishop John A Paddock. Of Washing
ton State, and has been attached to the FRO
Cathedral for the last two years. IN that time
he has become acquainted with the social con-
ditions Of the neighborhood and when he says
that the tendency seems to be downward IN
stead Of upward, and that the police instead OF
assisting IN the amelioration OF the conullionS
there deliberately and Systematically oostruct
and retard the work he speaks with positive
knowledge.


Speaking Of the conditions on the East Slde
yesterday. Mr.. Paddock said:


The work here certainly merits the earnest
consideration Of thoughtful men interested IN
the welfare Of the city. There is a growing uIi-
rest The conditions well calculated 10
breed anarchy and eventual violence. one uoes
not need 70 be an alarmist to see the pIiLom9 pI
ahead. We need encouragement from SUI stIVHs -
men The rich men Of the city who mo II
dfficult TO interest their in business en-
terprises should encourage some or theh 70
come over here and take part in our extremely
interesting work There ought TO be a coiiese
or university settlement on every BLOCK


A PICTURE OF EAST SIDE CONDITIONS.


Turning to a reporter. the young rector SAID
with more than usual gravity and earnestness:


Suppose that you were the child Of drunkaro.
here in this tenement district, or that your

full articles.headline: SUICIDE OF NEWsPAPER MAN
full articles.article:
Harrisburg Penn, Sept. 29.-George H. Welshons,
Of the best known newspaper men In Pennsyl-
vania committed suicide by severing the arteries
on his with penknife this evening in bed
room of a Harrisburg hotel. Weshons had
been drinking hard since he came to this city
two weeks ago. and labored under the hallucnaton
that he pursued by enemies He left this mes
sage. which written in a clear hand, on the
wall of the room: Facing my God, die innocent
and believing in my wife's fidelity. The future will
aCquit me- Welshons was formerly member of
the State Committee, and in the last GovernOrship
convention he had charge of the press bureau at
the Republican State headquarters.

full articles.headline:
BISHOP HAS PROOF ENOUGH

WELL EQUIPPED FOR THE FIGHT
AGAINST POLICE OPPRESSION ON .


THE EAST SIDE.
full articles.article:
Bishop Potter is in position 10 make puh,,o
conclusive proof of downright oppression nv,
the police Of the Eldridgest station Of scores Of
people who have come within the influence of
the parish work Of the Pro-Cathedral in stan
ton-st. He viii be able. If he so das,ras 80
show that petty prosecutions by the officers %
the law have made the work of Christian mon
and women who are trying to better the CON


ditions of the poor extremely hard in the lower
East Side. That he will work and talk v,sor-

full articles.headline: FIVE CAPTURED AFTER A CRUISE.
full articles.article:
Five men arrested yesterday by Acting Cap
tain Maude. OF the Hamiton-ave. police station.
after he had been cruising in the Atlantic Basin
in search OF them for some time. The Pennsyl-
vania Railroad had been missing pig iron from
barge on the South Brooklyn waterfront The po-
lice learned that several men leaving pig iron
at McCormacks junk shop. No. 10 Harrison-st.
The men were finally found, and escaped on a

full articles.headline:
NEW CONTROL OF CoAsTWIsE COMPANY.

CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO WILL SHIP COAL TO


EW-ENGLAND PORTS.
full articles.article:
Newport News. Va, Sept. % (SpeciaD.-The
Chesapeake and Ohio Railway recently secured the
entire stock Of the Coastwise Steamship Company
and now controls it outright. The Coastwise COM
pany is engaged in shipping coal from Newport
News to New-Engand ports. 1t owns three ocean
tugs fifteen large coal barges and charters three
ocean steamers. 1t is doing probably a larger
coal business than any other coastwise shipping
company.


1t is announced to-day that beginning on Mon
day, the price Of Pocahontas steam coal will be
advanced 10 cents ton, due to the heavy demand
for steam coal caused by the Pennsylvania strike
AS far as known the Chesapeake and Ohio Rail
way, operating here. win not increase the price
of it's New River steam coal for which there is a
heavier demand now than ever before.

full articles.headline: pOSTuASTER REIvBrRSED
full articles.article:
Washington. Sept 90 CSpeciaD-Through the
efforts Of Congressman James F. Stewart of the
With New-Jersey Congress District. the Postoffice
Department has allowed a reimbursement OF POST
master McMuen. of Rochelle Park N J.. for $40
in stamps stolen from the postolce at that place.
Mr. Stewart has also secured pensions for John
Terhune Of Hackensack. n. j., and James Hand.
Of Paterson, n. j. Application for postoffice at
Hudson Heights, Bergen County, n. j., was made
by the same Congressman

full articles.headline: BRYAN IN NEW-JERSEY.
full articles.article:
A conference of the New-Jersey Democratic State
Committee was held yesterday afternoon at the
headquarters in Jersey City 1t decided to
have Mr.. Bryan speak in Jersey City October 25
The meeting will be held under the auspices of the
Hudson County Democratic Committee. with
view OF patching up the differences between the
local committee and Chairman Courley. The State
Committee completed arrangements for the con-
vention of the New-Jersey Democratic Clubs In
Trenton on October Is.

full articles.headline:
PRICE OF SILVER INCREASED.

FIXED AT 81 CENTS AN OUNCE BY THE DIRECTOR


OF THE MINT.
full articles.article:
Washington, Sept. 29.-Owing to the advance in
the price OF silver the Director OF the Mint. Mr..
Roberts, to-day increased the price to be paid by
the Government for silver purchased from So cents
10 81 cents a standard ounce. The Government at
present purchases only such silver is contained
in gold deposits from the Klondike and other gold
producing sections Under the existing statute all
silver In gold deposits is paid for at the market
price The price has advanced steadily since 1895.
when It touched n cents for a standard ounce. The
new price is to go into effect on Monday.


The Director of the Mint also has changed the
Indian rupee from its silver to it's gold value to go
Although England placed India gold basis
some time ago, official informatan was received
to that effect until recently The silver rupee had
previously been the standard Indian coin. and was
valued 20.5 cents. Under the gold standard the
sovereign succeeds the rupee the standard, and
hereafter the rupee will be reckoned at its gold
value. 32.4 cents

full articles.headline: rHE on GUARD AT NEN.HArEN.
full articles.article:
New-Haven. Conn. Sept 29.-The Old Guard, Of
New-York. commanded by Major S. Ellis Briggs.
came New-Haven to-day as guests of the I'd
Company. Governors Foot Guards. The business
blocks and many private houses were decorated
in honor Of the visitors After a tour about the
city they entertained at luncheon at the
home OF Major Edward Clark of the Foot Guards
their visitors attended by an escort of police
paraded the principal streets of the city and at
o'clock dinner served at the Hotel Tontine.

full articles.headline:
WORLDS RAILWAY CONGRESS IN 1901

AMERICAN INVITATION ACCEPTED AT THE


MEETING JUST CLOSING IN PARIS.
full articles.article:
The next International Railway Congress will be
held in Washington in October, 1904. cable dis
patch from w. F. Allen. secretary of the American
Railway Association announcing that fact was re-
ceived yesterday the offices OF the association.
Mr.. Allen who is of the American delegates to
the International Railway Congress which has been
in session in the French capital during the last
week says that pressing invitation by the dele
gates from this country had been extended to the
Congress- and that the members of that body had
informed Mr. Allen of their acceptance.


The following officials of American railways have
been In attendance at the sixth session OF the In
ternational Congress- which closed yesterday: L.
F. Loree general manager Pennsylvania lines west
of Pittsburg; ]. Ramsey, jr., v!ce-presdent and
general manager Wabash; j. T. Harahan. second
vice-president Illinois Central; c. w Buchholz
chief engineer Erie; s T. Crapo general manager
Flint and Pere Marquette; G. L. BretZ. general
manager West Virginia Central and Pittsburg; Paul
Didier assistant chief engineer Pittsburg and
WESTERN c. P. Clark director New-York New
Haven and Hartford: P. H. Dudley. inspecting an
gineer New-York Central: DR. c. B. Dudley. chem
ist Pennsylvania: A NJ. Gibbs. assistant mechanical
engineer Pennsylvania; Colonel James L. Taylor.
Pennsylvania: Martin a. Knapp chairman OF the
Interstate Commerce Commission, and W. F. Allen,
secretary of the American Railway Association.

full articles.headline: cHARGED WITH BREAKING AND ENTERING.
full articles.article:
Montclair, n. j., Sept % (SpeciaD.-Henry Dob
bins said to be a New-York business man, was
held in $500 bail by Recorder Yost to-day on a
charge of breaking and entering. made by Miss
Dora Taft. Dobbins boarded with the complainant
during the summer. He refused 1t Is said TO pay
a bill Of $32 for the use of a barn as a storage place
for his automobile He paid his board bill yester-
day. before returning TO New York out declined
pay the bill for storage and. is alleged sawed
the lock off the barn and got his automobile when
bir

full articles.headline: COTTAGES ROBBED AT LONG BRAycH.
full articles.article:
Long Branch. ". J., Sept. % (SpecaD.-The Daniel
DouShe-ty cottage. in Ocean-ave.. at the West End
occupied by Fritz Loeb. OF No. 541 Madison-aye.
New-York and the Lane cottage, In Chelsea-sve.
where Uriah Herman and family are living, were
entered by thieves at early hour this morning
Mr. Loeb's loss is said TO be 1900. which includes
s1s5 in cash. a watch and chain and breastpin.
the latter being a highly priced gem. Mr.. Her
mans loss was small. The thieves were discovered
in time to prevent wholesale robbery, but they
escaped and stin at large.

full articles.headline: AMERICAN FLAG PULLED DOWN IN MEXICO
full articles.article:
San Antonio, Tex, Sept. 29.-United States Consul
w. w Mills, at Chihuahua. Mex, has sent note
to the Federal authorities here and also the
State Department at Washington detailing an in
suit to the American flag his consulate
September 16. the anniversary of Mexican inde-
pendence. by mob of Mexcans. He had hoisted
the United States and Mexican flags in honor of
the day. and the mob tore down the United States

full articles.headline: TWO NAVAL VESSELS FOR SALE.
full articles.article:
washington Sept. alt has been decided 20 sell
the old single turret monitor Nantucket and the tug
Cheyenne A Naval Board recently appraised the
former at $50 and the latter 5000. No bids
were received on September q. when proposals
to be opened for the purchase OF the ships.
and bids will be invited again.

full articles.headline: PRESIDENCY OF SOUTHERN PACIFIC.
full articles.article:
San Francisco Sept. 2s-"The Examiner to-day
says that the latest gossip in Southern Pacific
circles is that James Speyer. Charles H. Tweed and
D. o. Mills as a special committee of the director
ate have offered H e Huntington the presidency
of the company, but that he has declined 1t on the
ground that his duties first vce-president OF the
road together with the work of looking after the
large fortune left him by his uncle. will more than
occupy his time


The officials who indulging in talk of this
character assert that H. Z. Huntington does not
want outsider president. His particular can
didate for the place is the third cepresident j..
G. Stubbs. He also wants. 1t is said. Edwin Haw-
ley. of New-York. to succeed c. P. Huntington as
president of the Pacific Mail

full articles.headline: HOBsoy ASKS SIN MONTHS LEAVE.
full articles.article:
washington. Sept 2s.-Lleutenant Hobson has sp-
piled to the Navy Department for six months
leave OF absence because OF trouble with his eyes
He has experienced considerable pain In his eyes
OF late. particularly when exposed 70 a strong
light. and Il Is understood that specialist has
recommended a complete rest for six months.

land. the Lake Shore line, and also crosses the
Lake Shore at Goshen, Ind is, President Gala
way of the NewYork Central said last January
profitable feeder the Vanderbilt system to
which it brings interchanging business from its
lines extending south and Columbus and
Cincinnati, Louisville and Indianapolis Peoria and
St. Louis.

full articles.headline:
METH0D1sTs OPPOSE FAITH CURE.

BISHOP M'CABE REPRIMANDs CLERGYMAN FOR


HERETICAL DOCTRINES.
full articles.article:
North Tonawanda, N Y, Sept. pa sensation
was sprung the Genesee Methodist Conference
when 1t learned that Bishop McCabe had
called a clergyman before him and threatened him
with discipline unless he desisted from preaching
heretical doctrines The preacher taught the doc
trines of organization called the Christian and
Missionary Alliance, Of which DR.. Simpson, of
Newly orf. is the leader This believes in
the laying on Of hands for the cure of physical i'll
The clergyman used his influence for the
advancement of the faith healing ideas until there
has been much division and some Withdrawals
from his church

full articles.headline:
PROGRESS OF CENSUS WORK.

THE BUREAU WILL BEGIN TO ANNOUNCE PoPu-


LATIoN OF STATES THIS WEEK.
full articles.article:
LATIoN OF STATES THIS WEEK.


washington, Sept. 29-The Census Bureau to-
day finished the enumeration of all the cities in
the United States of 25.OOO inha abitants with
the exception OF Los Angeles Cal, and
Seattle and Tacoma Wash. The work Of an
nouncing the population OF States will come next
beginning with Arkansas probably next Monde
or Tuesday. The States will be announced in short
bulletins giving the total population. increase over
the two preceding census reports. the popula alton
by counties and the population OF each Of the
under 25,Ooo' Including all the incorporated towns
within the State limits. II is hoped to complete
the work on the States by the time Congress
assemblies, after which the vital statistics will be
pushed.


It IS probable that the present census will cost
in the neighborhood Of S15OOO,O00.

again. however. by policemen who had been sta
toned at the entrance to the pier In court the
prisoners were held in $3.50 bail suspicious per-

full articles.headline:
THROWS LAMP AT WoMEN's FEET.

woRKINGMANs ACT IMPERILs THE LIFE


OF PEDESTRIAN
full articles.article:
OF PEDESTRIAN.


Mrs. Margaret Gilman. eighty-three years old.
OF No. 273 Madson-ave.. with her maid, Miss c.
Mcguire, was passing No II East hirty-eighth-st.
yesterday afternoon. when lighted lamp struck
the sidewalk directly In front of her. The lamp
was broken and the oil famed up setting fire TO
the clothing OF Mrs. Gilman. Miss Mcguire
promptly beat out the flames with her hands. Sc
verely burning them and her arms in doing so.
Mrs. Gilman not injured. The two women
entered a cab and were driven home


The lamp was thrown from the second floor of
the building by Fritz Gunther. decorator. who
lives at No. SlS Cedar Place. in The Bronx. He
was at work in the building. when the wick of the
lamp suddenly hared UP. Fearing that the infam-
mable material with which he was working would
become ignited, Gunther grabbed the lamp and
threw II into the street. Mrs Gilman refused 70
make n complaint against Gunther, and he not
arrested.

full articles.headline: BORN WTTHOrT ARns OR LEGS.
full articles.article:
Mrs. Mary Catherwood, wife of Samuel Gather
wood. of No. 35l Fifteenth-ave.. Newark. n. J..
gave birth yesterday to a child without arms or
otherwise.

full articles.headline:
SUIT AGAINST A LUMBER FIRM.

PLA1NFIELD MILL OWNER INJURED BY A BREAK


ING sCAFFoLD WANTS $4,000
full articles.article:
Plainfeld, n. Y, Sept 2e.-Suit has been begun
by J. D. Spcer. of the firm of Spcer & Hubbard
mill owners. in this city, for 1000 against the
lumber firm of Boice, Runyon & Co., for injuries
received last spring by the breaking of a scaffold
IN the lumber yard. The suit is in reality against
the Travellers Insurance Company. but has to be
brought against the firm, which insured
against accidents of this kind.


Mr.. Spicer and John D. Runyon the scat
fold twenty feet from the ground, examining um-
Der. when the scaffold broke. Mr. Runyon died
from his injuries but Mr.. Spicer after long ILL
ness Is able to be about again.

people In the narrow columns.
